The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$.
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Submonoid to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a submonoid is defined within the context of a monoid. A submonoid is a subset of a monoid that includes the identity element and is closed under the monoid's operation. This definition requires understanding what a monoid is, but it does not specifically require any knowledge of symmetric groups.

A symmetric group, on the other hand, is a specific type of group consisting of all the bijective functions on a set of a certain size, forming a group under the operation of composition. While a symmetric group is an example of a group (and indeed a monoid, since every group is a monoid), the general concept of a submonoid does not depend on the concept of a symmetric group. The definition of a submonoid can be applied to any monoid, not just symmetric groups.

Therefore, the definition of a submonoid does not inherently require the concept of a symmetric group. It is a broader concept applicable to any monoid, whether or not it is a symmetric group.
